byline.contributor: Jack Begg and Elisa Cho contributed research.

abstract: Preliminary findings by New Jersey police show mathemitician John F Nash Jr and his wife Alicia Nash were not wearing seatbelts when they were thrown from back seat of their taxi in deadly crash on New Jersey Turnpike; city officials and advocates supporting changes to seatbelt laws say that riders are under mistaken impression that it is safe to go without seatbelts in backseat.
lead_paragraph: Seatbelt campaigns have been undermined, in part, by a cultural mind-set that not using one in the back is somehow safer and by what some see as mixed messages in state laws.

headline.main: Deaths of Math Genius John F. Nash Jr. and Wife Show Need to Use Seatbelts in Back, Experts Say
headline.print_headline: Deaths of Math Genius and Wife Show Need to Use Belts in Back Seat, Experts Say

snippet: Seatbelt campaigns have been undermined, in part, by a cultural mind-set that not using one in the back is somehow safer and by what some see as mixed messages in state laws.
